entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 6 Randomized Computation
entry.content:
What if Turing machine models have access to a source of randomness?

This would allow to compute more in same time/space, at the price of possibly not giving correct answer with small probability.

Current consensus: Randomization only gives

  • Polynomial saving in time
  • Constant factor saving in space

Because of hardness-based pseudo-random generator.

Exponential time: E=DTIME(2O(n))=ULâˆ’SIZE(2O(n))E=DTIME(2^{O(n)})=U_L-SIZE(2^{O(n)})E=DTIME(2O(n))=ULâ€‹âˆ’SIZE(2O(n)). (By corollary 2)

Recall that SIZE(2n/n)SIZE(2^n/n)SIZE(2n/n) includes every Boolean function on nnn variables, making non-uniform inclusion EâŠ†SIZE(2O(n))E\subseteq SIZE(2^{O(n)})EâŠ†SIZE(2O(n)).

Corresponding randomized complexity class BPPBPPBPP.

Theorem 33 (Impagliazzo and Wigderson). If there exists LâˆˆEL\in ELâˆˆE s.t. for every nnn and every Boolean circuit CCC computing LLL on input length nnn, the size of CCC must be 2Î©(n)2^{\Omega(n)}2Î©(n), then P=BPPP=BPPP=BPP.

Probabilistic Turing Machines

Give a probabilistic Turing machine an extra read-only and read-once tape which is pre-initialized with uniform and independent random bits. The tape head is allow to only stop or move forward.

Thus everything related to the Turing machines becomes a random variable.

Different kinds of Errors

Zero-sided error aka Las Vegas computation: Turing machine halt in a state â€œ?â€ with small probability and require correct answer otherwise.

One-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives.

Two-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives and false positives.

ğŸ“–Definition 19. Let MMM be a probabilistic Turing machine and LLL a language.

  • MMM computes LLL with zero-sided error if for all xxx we have Prâ¡[M(x)=?]â‰¤14\Pr[M(x)=?]\le\frac{1}{4}Pr[M(x)=?]â‰¤41â€‹, that M(x)âˆˆ{yes,?}M(x)\in\{yes,?\}M(x)âˆˆ{yes,?} when xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL, and that M(x)âˆˆ{no,?}M(x)\in\{no,?\}M(x)âˆˆ{no,?} when xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL.
  • MMM computes LLL with one-sided error if for all xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=yes]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]â‰¥43â€‹ and for all xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL we have M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no.
  • MMM computes LLL with two-sided error if for all xâˆˆLx\in LxâˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=yes]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]â‰¥43â€‹ and for all xâˆˆÌ¸Lx\not\in Lxî€ âˆˆL we have Prâ¡[M(x)=no]â‰¥34\Pr[M(x)=no]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=no]â‰¥43â€‹.

ğŸ“–Definition 20. Let T:Nâ†’NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:Nâ†’N and S:Nâ†’NS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:Nâ†’N be functions with T(n)â‰¥nT(n)\ge nT(n)â‰¥n.

  • Then ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n)), RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n)) and BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded probabilistic Turing machine with zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.
  • ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n)), RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n)) and BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded probabilistic Turing machine that always halt having zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.

For space bounded randomized classes, we assume that the Turing machine always halts! Because otherwise these three classes would end up containing NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))!

Define log-space/polynomial time bounded classes:

ZPL=ZPSPACE(logâ¡n)RP=RSPACE(logâ¡n)BPL=BPSPACE(logâ¡n)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))ZPL=ZPSPACE(\log n)\\RP=RSPACE(\log n)\\BPL=BPSPACE(\log n)\\ZPP=ZPTIME(n^{O(1)})\\RP=RTIME(n^{O(1)})\\BPP=BPTIME(n^{O(1)})ZPL=ZPSPACE(logn)RP=RSPACE(logn)BPL=BPSPACE(logn)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))

Trivially, LâŠ†ZPLâŠ†RLâŠ†BPLL\subseteq ZPL\subseteq RL\subseteq BPLLâŠ†ZPLâŠ†RLâŠ†BPL; PâŠ†ZPPâŠ†RPâŠ†BPPP\subseteq ZPP\subseteq RP\subseteq BPPPâŠ†ZPPâŠ†RPâŠ†BPP.

Itâ€™s also easy to see that RLâŠ†NLRL\subseteq NLRLâŠ†NL and RPâŠ†NPRP\subseteq NPRPâŠ†NP.

Simple upper bound for BPPBPPBPP (not tight): similar to theorem 10, BPPâŠ†PSPACEBPP\subseteq PSPACEBPPâŠ†PSPACE.

For BPLBPLBPL, BPLâŠ†DSPACE(logâ¡3/2n)BPL\subseteq DSPACE(\log^{3/2}n)BPLâŠ†DSPACE(log3/2n).

Success Amplification

Error probability of 1/41/41/4 is large, but we can reduce it by independently running multiple times.

For zero-sided error, we wonâ€™t stop until we get non-unknown answer.

For one-sided error, if some trial accepts, we accept. otherwise we reject.

For two-sided error, we decided the answer by the majority of trials.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 3. Let X1,â‹¯â€‰,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1â€‹,â‹¯,Xkâ€‹ be independent Boolean variables s.t. Prâ¡[Xi=1]â‰¥Ïµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\epsilonPr[Xiâ€‹=1]â‰¥Ïµ. Then

Prâ¡[âˆ€i:Xi=0]<expâ¡(âˆ’kÏµ)\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]\lt\exp(-k\epsilon)Pr[âˆ€i:Xiâ€‹=0]<exp(âˆ’kÏµ)

By independence,

Prâ¡[âˆ€i:Xi=0]=âˆiPrâ¡[Xi=0]<(1âˆ’Ïµ)kâ‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’kÏµ).\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]=\prod_i\Pr[X_i=0]\lt(1-\epsilon)^k\le\exp(-k\epsilon).Pr[âˆ€i:Xiâ€‹=0]=iâˆâ€‹Pr[Xiâ€‹=0]<(1âˆ’Ïµ)kâ‰¤exp(âˆ’kÏµ).

(by 1+xâ‰¤expâ¡(x)1+x\le\exp(x)1+xâ‰¤exp(x))

Apply this to zero-sided and one-sided errors:

  • Define XiX_iXiâ€‹ to indicate whether trial iii gives the correct output.
  • Instead of having error probability 1/41/41/4, we actually assume that error probability for once is less than 1âˆ’1p(n)1-\frac{1}{p(n)}1âˆ’p(n)1â€‹ and still achieve error probability expâ¡(âˆ’q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(âˆ’q(n)) for all by running k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n) trials, which is polynomial number.

For two-sided error:

ğŸ¤”Lemma 4 (Chernoff-Hoeffding Bound). Let XXX be the sum of kkk independent Boolean random variables. Assume Î¼Lâ‰¤E[X]â‰¤Î¼H\mu_L\le\mathbb E[X]\le\mu_HÎ¼Lâ€‹â‰¤E[X]â‰¤Î¼Hâ€‹, t>0t>0t>0. Then

Prâ¡[X<Î¼Lâˆ’t]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2t2/k),Prâ¡[X>Î¼H+t]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2t2/k).\Pr[X<\mu_L-t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k),\\\Pr[X>\mu_H+t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k).Pr[X<Î¼Lâ€‹âˆ’t]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2t2/k),Pr[X>Î¼Hâ€‹+t]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2t2/k).

We define the random indicator XiX_iXiâ€‹ to indicate whether trial iii gave correct output. We assume that Prâ¡[Xi=1]â‰¥12+Ïµ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\frac{1}{2}+\epsilonPr[Xiâ€‹=1]â‰¥21â€‹+Ïµ and kkk is odd. Let X=âˆ‘i=1kXiX=\sum_{i=1}^kX_iX=âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹Xiâ€‹, we have E[X]â‰¥k2+kÏµ\mathbb E[X]\ge\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonE[X]â‰¥2kâ€‹+kÏµ. Applying Chernoff-Hoeffding bound, we have

Prâ¡[X<k2]=Prâ¡[X<Î¼Lâˆ’kÏµ]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’2(kÏµ)2/k)=expâ¡(âˆ’2kÏµ2)\Pr[X<\frac{k}{2}]=\Pr[X<\mu_L-k\epsilon]\le\exp(-2(k\epsilon)^2/k)\\=\exp(-2k\epsilon^2)Pr[X<2kâ€‹]=Pr[X<Î¼Lâ€‹âˆ’kÏµ]â‰¤exp(âˆ’2(kÏµ)2/k)=exp(âˆ’2kÏµ2)

using Î¼L=k2+kÏµ\mu_L=\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonÎ¼Lâ€‹=2kâ€‹+kÏµ. Instead of have error probability 1/41/41/4, we assume error probability for once just less than 1/2âˆ’1/p(n)1/2-1/p(n)1/2âˆ’1/p(n) and achieve error probability expâ¡(âˆ’q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(âˆ’q(n)) by running k=p(n)2q(n)2k=\frac{p(n)^2q(n)}{2}k=2p(n)2q(n)â€‹ independent trials.

These analysis applies to both polynomial-time bounded and log-space bounded randomized complexity classes.

Polynomial Identity Testing

Donâ€™t know:

  1. Whether randomized classes have complete problem;
  2. Any hierarchy results for randomized classes.

PIT

Polynomial Identity Testing (PIT): Testing whether a polynomial is identically zero.

PIT problem is efficiently solvable in randomized polynomial time but not known to be solvable deterministically in polynomial time.

ğŸ“–Definition 21 (Arithmetic circuit). An arithmetic circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is either 000 or 222.
  2. A labeling â„“\ellâ„“ for the nodes VVV.
  3. A choice of mmm outputs gates o1,â‹¯â€‰,omâˆˆVo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1â€‹,â‹¯,omâ€‹âˆˆV.

Nodes VVV corresponds to gates, edges AAA corresponds to wires. Nodes of in-degree 000 are input gates. The labeling function satisfies âˆ€\forallâˆ€ gates ggg:

  1. If fanin of ggg is 000, â„“(g)âˆˆ{1,x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn}\ell(g)\in\{1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{1,x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹}.
  2. If fanin of ggg is 222, â„“(g)âˆˆ{+,Ã—,âˆ’}\ell(g)\in\{+,\times,-\}â„“(g)âˆˆ{+,Ã—,âˆ’}.

Such an arithmetic circuit compute a polynomial pâˆˆR[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]p\in R[x_1,\cdots,x_n]pâˆˆR[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹] for any Abelian ring RRR. é˜¿è´å°”ç¯

Usually we consider arithmetic circuits w.r.t. ring.

AFIT

aka Arithmetic formula identity testing

A variant of PIT: input polynomial is given by an arithmetic formula.

Instance: Arithmetic formula computing the polynomial P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆZ[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆZ[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹].

Question: Is P(x)â‰¡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)â‰¡0?

A simple randomized algorithm: simply choose number a1,â‹¯â€‰,anâˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯â€‰,4m}a_1,\cdots,a_n\in\{1,2,\cdots,4m\}a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹âˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯,4m} independently and uniformly at random, where mmm is the size of the given formula, evaluate P(a1,â‹¯â€‰,an)P(a_1,\cdots, a_n)P(a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹) and answer accordingly.

Using Schwartz-Zippel lemma to analyze error probability.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 5 (Schwartz-Zippel lemma). Let F\mathbb FF be a field, let P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆF[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb F[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆF[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹] be a non-zero polynomial of total degree at most ddd. Let SâŠ†FS\subseteq\mathbb FSâŠ†F, and pick a1,â‹¯â€‰,anâˆˆSa_1,\cdots, a_n\in Sa1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹âˆˆS independently and uniformly at random. Then

Prâ¡[P(a1,â‹¯â€‰,an)=0]â‰¤dâˆ£Sâˆ£.\Pr[P(a_1,\cdots,a_n)=0]\le\frac{d}{|S|}.Pr[P(a1â€‹,â‹¯,anâ€‹)=0]â‰¤âˆ£Sâˆ£dâ€‹.

Proof by induction on nnn.

So the error probability is decided by mmm, at most 1/41/41/4.

ACIT

aka arithmetic circuit identity testing

Instance: Arithmetic circuit computing the polynomial P(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)âˆˆZ[x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹)âˆˆZ[x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹].

Question: Is P(x)â‰¡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)â‰¡0?

Circuit of size mmm has at most mmm multiplication gates. The degree of the polynomial computed is at most 2m2^m2m. The same approach as in arithmetic formula calls for draw random number from 1,â‹¯â€‰,2m+21,\cdots,2^{m+2}1,â‹¯,2m+2. (exponential!)

To remedy this, we switch to modular arithmetic with randomly chosen prime modulus. Use prime number theorem to analyze error probability.

Let Ï€(x)\pi(x)Ï€(x) be the number of prime number less than xxx. By prime number theory,

Ï€(x)âˆ¼xlnâ¡x.\pi(x)\sim\frac{x}{\ln x}.Ï€(x)âˆ¼lnxxâ€‹.

An Alternative Characterization of Time Bounded Classes

We have alternative characterization of BPPBPPBPP. Also there are similar alternatives of ZPPZPPZPP and RPRPRP.

Proposition 4. Let LLL be a language. Then LâˆˆBPPL\in BPPLâˆˆBPP iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t. âˆ€x\forall xâˆ€x:

xâˆˆLâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥34xâˆˆÌ¸Lâ‡’Prâ¡yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆÌ¸Lâ€²]â‰¥34x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\not\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}xâˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥43â€‹xî€ âˆˆLâ‡’yâˆˆ{0,1}q(âˆ£xâˆ£)Prâ€‹[âŸ¨x,yâŸ©î€ âˆˆLâ€²]â‰¥43â€‹

We say that the randomized computation uses q(âˆ£xâˆ£)q(|x|)q(âˆ£xâˆ£) random bits.

Using success amplification a randomized algorithm using RRR random bits and having error probability less than 1/41/41/4 can be transformed to a randomized algorithm using kRkRkR random bits and having error probability less than expâ¡(âˆ’k/8)\exp(-k/8)exp(âˆ’k/8) by running kkk trials and taking the majority vote.

Randomized Computation and the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

By definition, RPâŠ†NPRP\subseteq NPRPâŠ†NP.

But we donâ€™t know whether BPPâŠ†NPBPP\subseteq NPBPPâŠ†NP or NPâŠ†BPPNP\subseteq BPPNPâŠ†BPP.

We just guess: BPP=PBPP=PBPP=P thus BPPâŠ†NPBPP\subseteq NPBPPâŠ†NP.

But we can prove that BPPBPPBPP is contained in the second level of polynomial-time hierarchy.

It remains to prove the predicate is equivalent to â‹ƒi=1muiâŠ•Sx={0,1}m\bigcup_{i=1}^mu_i\oplus S_x=\{0,1\}^mâ‹ƒi=1mâ€‹uiâ€‹âŠ•Sxâ€‹={0,1}m.

Randomized Computation and Boolean Circuits

Everything that can be computed in polynomial-time by randomized algorithm can also be computed using Boolean circuits.

entry.summary:
æœ¬æ¬¡æ¯”èµ› é“¾æ¥

ç°åœ¨çš„æ°´å¹³åªèƒ½ç¢°ç¢° Div 3

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 5 The Polynomoial-Time Hierarchy
entry.content:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem HALTHALTHALT is a recursive enumerable language that is undecidable.

The polynomial-time hierarchy considers polynomial time and SATSATSAT instead of HALTHALTHALT.

Oracle Turing Machines

An oracle Turing machine M?M^?M? is equipped with an additional tape, the query tape, and has three new special states qask,qyes,qnoq_{ask},q_{yes},q_{no}qaskâ€‹,qyesâ€‹,qnoâ€‹. The query tape is a write-only tape.

The operation of M?M^?M? is defined relative to an oracle language AAA.

Denote M?M^?M? together with oracle language AAA by MAM^AMA.

Whenever MAM^AMA enters the state qaskq_{ask}qaskâ€‹:

  • Let zzz be the string of symbols written to the query tape. The query tape is reinitialized to a black tape.
  • If zâˆˆAz\in AzâˆˆA, computation resumes in the state qyesq_{yes}qyesâ€‹.
  • If zâˆˆÌ¸Az\not\in Azî€ âˆˆA, computation resumes in the state qnoq_{no}qnoâ€‹.

Define timeMA(x)time_{M^A}(x)timeMAâ€‹(x) and spaceMA(x)space_{M^A}(x)spaceMAâ€‹(x) for an oracle Turing machine with an oracle language AAA to be the number of computation steps and number of cells of work tape used during computation on input xxx. The same way we define time-bounded and space-bounded oracle Turing machines.

Then we need to define oracle versions of complexity classes. Straightforward to define time-bounded complexity classes, but be careful to define space-bounded complexity classes.

DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^A(T(n)),DSPACE^A(S(n)),NTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n)).

â—Problem for non-deterministic space-bounded oracle Turing machine: it may write very long strings to the oracle tape.

Solution: Requiring the oracle Turing machine to behave deterministically in the time between writing the first symbol to the oracle tape and making the oracle query. (deterministic oracle access)

Thus we define NSPACEA(S(n))NSPACE^A(S(n))NSPACEA(S(n)) as the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic oracle Turing machine with deterministic oracle access to oracle AAA.

The definition can be extended to other complexity classes.

PAP^APA and NPANP^ANPA for any oracle language AAA.

The oracle may be chosen from some class of languages. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages.

DTIMEC(T(n))=â‹ƒAâˆˆCDTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))=\bigcup_{A\in\mathcal C}DTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEC(T(n))=AâˆˆCâ‹ƒâ€‹DTIMEA(T(n))

Similarly we have DSPACEC(T(n))DSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))DSPACEC(T(n)), NTIMEC(T(n))NTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))NTIMEC(T(n)) and NSPACEC(T(n))NSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))NSPACEC(T(n)).

This again extends to all other complexity classes such as PNPP^{NP}PNP.

Turing Reductions

ğŸ“–Definition 17 (Turing reductions). Let L1L_1L1â€‹ and L2L_2L2â€‹ be languages. We say that L1L_1L1â€‹ log-space Turing machine reduces to L2L_2L2â€‹ (L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L2L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L2â€‹), if L1âˆˆLL2L_1\in L^{L_2}L1â€‹âˆˆLL2â€‹. Similarly we say L1L_1L1â€‹ polynomial time Turing reduces to L2L_2L2â€‹ (L1â‰¤TPL2L_1\le_T^PL_2L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L2â€‹), if L1âˆˆPL2L_1\in P^{L_2}L1â€‹âˆˆPL2â€‹.

It also satisfies transitivity.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 2. Transitivity.

  • L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L2,L2â‰¤Tlogâ¡L3â‡’L1â‰¤Tlogâ¡L3L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2,L_2\le_T^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{\log}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤Tlogâ€‹L3â€‹
  • L1â‰¤TPL2,L2â‰¤TPL3â‡’L1â‰¤TPL3L_1\le_T^{P}L_2,L_2\le_T^{P}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{P}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤TPâ€‹L3â€‹

ğŸ¤”Proposition 3. The class L,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under log-space Turing reductions. The class P,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under polynomial-time Turing machine.

The Polynomial-time Hierarchy via Oracles and Quantifiers

For a class of language C\mathcal CC, denote coCco\mathcal CcoC the class of complements of languages of C\mathcal CC.

coC={Lâ€¾âˆ£LâˆˆC}co\mathcal C=\{\overline L|L\in\mathcal C\}coC={Lâˆ£LâˆˆC}

ğŸ“–Definition 18 (polynomial-time hierarchy). Let Î”0P=Î£0P=Î 0P=P\Delta_0^P=\Sigma_0^P=\Pi_0^P=PÎ”0Pâ€‹=Î£0Pâ€‹=Î 0Pâ€‹=P. For iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0, define further Î”i+1P=PÎ£iP\Delta_{i+1}^P=P^{\Sigma_i^P}Î”i+1Pâ€‹=PÎ£iPâ€‹, Î£i+1P=NPÎ£iP\Sigma_{i+1}^P=NP^{\Sigma_i^P}Î£i+1Pâ€‹=NPÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î i+1P=coNPÎ£iP\Pi_{i+1}^P=coNP^{\Sigma_i^P}Î i+1Pâ€‹=coNPÎ£iPâ€‹. Finally, let Polynomial Hierarchy PH=â‹ƒiâ‰¥0Î£iPPH=\bigcup_{i\ge0}\Sigma_i^PPH=â‹ƒiâ‰¥0â€‹Î£iPâ€‹.

The classes Î”iP,Î£iP,Î iP\Delta_i^P,\Sigma_i^P,\Pi_i^PÎ”iPâ€‹,Î£iPâ€‹,Î iPâ€‹ are said to make up level iii of the polynomial-time hierarchy, and PHPHPH denotes the entire polynomial-time hierarchy.

Note that Î”1P=PP=P\Delta_1^P=P^P=PÎ”1Pâ€‹=PP=P, Î£1P=NPP=NP\Sigma_1^P=NP^P=NPÎ£1Pâ€‹=NPP=NP, Î 1P=coNPP=coNP\Pi_1^P=coNP^P=coNPÎ 1Pâ€‹=coNPP=coNP.

On second level, we have PNP,NPNP,coNPNPP^{NP}, NP^{NP}, coNP^{NP}PNP,NPNP,coNPNP, continuing ad infimum.

Straightforward:

Î”iPâŠ†Î£iPâˆ©Î iPâŠ†Î£iPâˆªÎ iPâŠ†Î”i+1P\Delta_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cap\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cup\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Delta_{i+1}^PÎ”iPâ€‹âŠ†Î£iPâ€‹âˆ©Î iPâ€‹âŠ†Î£iPâ€‹âˆªÎ iPâ€‹âŠ†Î”i+1Pâ€‹

ğŸ¯Theorem 27. PHâŠ†PSPACEPH\subseteq PSPACEPHâŠ†PSPACE.

Using polynomial space simply simulate the non-deterministic Turing machine same way as in proof of Theorem 10.

Then prove an equivalent definition of the classes Î£iP\Sigma_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î iP\Pi_i^PÎ iPâ€‹ in terms of quantifiers.

ğŸ¯Theorem 28. Let LLL be any language and let iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1. Then LâˆˆÎ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PLâˆˆÎ£iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆÎ iâˆ’1PL'\in\Pi_{i-1}^PLâ€²âˆˆÎ iâˆ’1Pâ€‹ s.t.

\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist y:|y|\le q(|x|)\and\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€y:âˆ£yâˆ£â‰¤q(âˆ£xâˆ£)â‡’âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²].\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall y:|y|\le q(|x|)\Rarr\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€y:âˆ£yâˆ£â‰¤q(âˆ£xâˆ£)â‡’âŸ¨x,yâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²].

ğŸ¤”Corollary 4. Let LLL be any language and let iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1. Then LâˆˆÎ£iPL\in\Sigma_i^PLâˆˆÎ£iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t.

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆƒqy1âˆ€qy2â‹¯Qiqyi:âŸ¨x,y1,y2,â‹¯â€‰,yiâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist^qy_1\forall^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆƒqy1â€‹âˆ€qy2â€‹â‹¯Qiqâ€‹yiâ€‹:âŸ¨x,y1â€‹,y2â€‹,â‹¯,yiâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],

where QiQ_iQiâ€‹ is âˆƒ\existâˆƒ if iii is odd, and âˆ€\forallâˆ€ if iii is even. Likewise, LâˆˆÎ iPL\in\Pi_i^PLâˆˆÎ iPâ€‹ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language Lâ€²âˆˆPL'\in PLâ€²âˆˆP s.t.

âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€qy1âˆƒqy2â‹¯Qiqyi:âŸ¨x,y1,y2,â‹¯â€‰,yiâŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall^qy_1\exist^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],âˆ€x:[xâˆˆLâ‡”âˆ€qy1â€‹âˆƒqy2â€‹â‹¯Qiqâ€‹yiâ€‹:âŸ¨x,y1â€‹,y2â€‹,â‹¯,yiâ€‹âŸ©âˆˆLâ€²],

where QiQ_iQiâ€‹ is âˆƒ\existâˆƒ if iii is even, and âˆ€\forallâˆ€ if iii is odd.

Generalize whether P=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNP to question whether Î”iP=Î£iP,Î£iP=Î iP\Delta_i^P=\Sigma_i^P,\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PÎ”iPâ€‹=Î£iPâ€‹,Î£iPâ€‹=Î iPâ€‹ for i>1i\gt1i>1.

ğŸ¯Theorem 29. If Î£iP=Î iP\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹=Î iPâ€‹ for some iâ‰¥1i\ge1iâ‰¥1 then PH=Î£iPPH=\Sigma_i^PPH=Î£iPâ€‹.

ç»§ç»­çœ‹ å¤©ä¹¦ã€‚

Completeness in the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

Î£iSAT\Sigma_iSATÎ£iâ€‹SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables Ïˆ=âˆƒx1âˆ€x2â‹¯QixiÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xi)\psi=\exist x_1\forall x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)Ïˆ=âˆƒx1â€‹âˆ€x2â€‹â‹¯Qiâ€‹xiâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xiâ€‹), where xjâˆˆ{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xjâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}njâ€‹ for all jjj and Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€ for even iii and âˆƒ\existâˆƒ for odd iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

Î iSAT\Pi_iSATÎ iâ€‹SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables Ïˆ=âˆ€x1âˆƒx2â‹¯QixiÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xi)\psi=\forall x_1\exist x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)Ïˆ=âˆ€x1â€‹âˆƒx2â€‹â‹¯Qiâ€‹xiâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xiâ€‹), where xjâˆˆ{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xjâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1}njâ€‹ for all jjj and Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€ for odd iii and âˆƒ\existâˆƒ for even iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

ğŸ¯Theorem 30. Î£iSAT\Sigma_iSATÎ£iâ€‹SAT is complete for Î£iP\Sigma_i^PÎ£iPâ€‹ and Î iSAT\Pi_iSATÎ iâ€‹SAT is complete for Î iP\Pi_i^PÎ iPâ€‹.

å‰é¢çš„æ¨è®º 4 éƒ½æ²¡æ‡‚â€¦â€¦è¿™ä¸ªè¯æ˜å°±æ›´ä¸æ‡‚äº†

In case of Qi=âˆƒQ_i=\existQiâ€‹=âˆƒ, we ended up with a CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

In case of Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€, we ended up with a DNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

ğŸ¯Theorem 31. If PHPHPH has a complete language, then PHPHPH collapses.

This follows since PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE has complete problems.

Collapses åœ¨æ­¤å¤„æŒ‡å¤šé¡¹å¼å±‚æ¬¡ç»“æ„ä¸­æŸä¸€å±‚ä»¥ä¸Šçš„æ‰€æœ‰çº§åˆ«éƒ½é‡åˆçš„æƒ…å†µã€‚

The Karp-Lipton Theorem

A possible way to prove Pâ‰ NPP\neq NPPî€ =NP would be to show that there is some language in NPNPNP that is not computed by a family of polynomial size Boolean circuits, i.e., that NPâŠ†Ì¸P/polyNP\not\subseteq P/polyNPî€ âŠ†P/poly.

This is stronger than Pâ‰ NPP\neq NPPî€ =NP since PâŠ†P/polyP\subseteq P/polyPâŠ†P/poly. It turns out that it is not stronger than the assumption that the polynomial-time hierarchy does not collapse.

ğŸ¯Theorem 32. Suppose that NPâŠ†P/polyNP\subseteq P/polyNPâŠ†P/poly. Then PH=Î£2Pâˆ©Î 2PPH=\Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PPH=Î£2Pâ€‹âˆ©Î 2Pâ€‹.

Proof by Theorem 29, Corollary 4.

entry.title: ç®—æ³•å’Œè®¡ç®—å¤æ‚åº¦ 4 Reductions and Completeness
entry.content:
Reductions

NP-completeness: by polynomial-time many-one reductions (aka Karp reductions)

Studying completeness of P and NL: by log-space many-one reduction. Also too powerful for completeness inside L.

ğŸ“–Definition 14 (Log-space reductions). Let L1âŠ†Î£1âˆ—L_1\subseteq\Sigma_1^*L1â€‹âŠ†Î£1âˆ—â€‹ and L2âŠ†Î£2âˆ—L_2\subseteq\Sigma_2^*L2â€‹âŠ†Î£2âˆ—â€‹ be languages. A log-space many-one reduction from L1L_1L1â€‹ to L2L_2L2â€‹ is a function f:Î£1âˆ—â†’Î£2âˆ—f:\Sigma_1^*\rarr\Sigma_2^*f:Î£1âˆ—â€‹â†’Î£2âˆ—â€‹ s.t.

  1. There exists a log-space Turing machine computing fff.
  2. For all xâˆˆÎ£1âˆ—x\in\Sigma_1^*xâˆˆÎ£1âˆ—â€‹, we have xâˆˆL1â‡”f(x)âˆˆL2x\in L_1\Lrarr f(x)\in L_2xâˆˆL1â€‹â‡”f(x)âˆˆL2â€‹.

Denote: L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L2L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L2â€‹

The definition of polynomial-time many-one reduction (L1â‰¤mpL2L_1\le_m^pL_2L1â€‹â‰¤mpâ€‹L2â€‹) is similar (simply using polynomial-time Turing machine instead).

ğŸ“–Definition 15 (â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-hard/complete). Let LLL be a language and C\mathcal CC be a class of languages. We say that LLL is â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-hard for C\mathcal CC if for every Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in\mathcal CLâ€²âˆˆC we have Lâ€²â‰¤mlogâ¡LL'\le_m^{\log}LLâ€²â‰¤mlogâ€‹L. We say LLL is â‰¤mlogâ¡\le_m^{\log}â‰¤mlogâ€‹-complete if we additionally have LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC.

Reduction has property of transitivity.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 1. L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L2,L2â‰¤mlogâ¡L3â‡’L1â‰¤mlogâ¡L3L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2, L_2\le_m^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_m^{\log}L_3L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L2â€‹,L2â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L3â€‹â‡’L1â€‹â‰¤mlogâ€‹L3â€‹.

Let M1M_1M1â€‹ and M2M_2M2â€‹ be log-space Turing machines computing f1:L1â†’L2,f2:L2â†’L3f_1:L_1\to L_2,f_2:L_2\to L_3f1â€‹:L1â€‹â†’L2â€‹,f2â€‹:L2â€‹â†’L3â€‹, respectively. It suffices to show that f=f2âˆ˜f1f=f_2\circ f_1f=f2â€‹âˆ˜f1â€‹ is computable by log-space Turing machine MMM.

On input xxx, we simulate M2M_2M2â€‹ with virtual input tape f1(x)f_1(x)f1â€‹(x). We maintain a counter giving the position of the virtual input tape head of M2M_2M2â€‹. To simulate step of computation of M2M_2M2â€‹, we start simulating M1M_1M1â€‹ on input xxx, counting and then discarding the output symbols by M1M_1M1â€‹ until the output symbol where the virtual input tape head is placed is to be written. Then the step of M2M_2M2â€‹ can be complete.

Let xxx be of length n=âˆ£nâˆ£n=|n|n=âˆ£nâˆ£. âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=2O(logâ¡n)=nO(1)|f(x)|=2^{O(\log n)}=n^{O(1)}âˆ£f(x)âˆ£=2O(logn)=nO(1), storing the position of the virtual tape head as well as the work tapes of M1M_1M1â€‹ and M2M_2M2â€‹ takes space O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn).

æˆ‘è§‰å¾—ä¹ŸæŒºæ˜¾ç„¶çš„å‘€ï¼Œç”¨ä¸¤å°å¯¹æ•°ç©ºé—´çš„å›¾çµæœºæ¨¡æ‹Ÿï¼Œæ€»ç©ºé—´ä»ç„¶æ˜¯å¯¹æ•°çš„ã€‚

Then we define reduction âª¯\preceqâª¯ between languages.

ğŸ“–Definition 16. A language LLL is hard for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions if for all Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in\mathcal CLâ€²âˆˆC we have Lâ€²âª¯LL'\preceq LLâ€²âª¯L. A language LLL is complete for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions if LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC in addition to begin hard for C\mathcal CC under âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions.

Complexity class has an important property: the complexity class is closed under reductions.

We say C\mathcal CC is closed w.r.t. âª¯\preceqâª¯ reductions, if whenever Lâ€²âª¯LL'\preceq LLâ€²âª¯L and LâˆˆCL\in\mathcal CLâˆˆC, we also have Lâ€²âˆˆCL'\in CLâ€²âˆˆC. Proof omitted.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 2. The classes L,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under log-space many-one reductions. The classes P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under polynomial-time many-one reductions.

NL-completeness

The basic NL-complete problem is given by connectivity in a directed graph (STCONSTCONSTCON).

STCON

The instance: Directed graph DDD and nodes sss and ttt.

Question: Is there a directed path in DDD from sss to ttt?

ğŸ¯Theorem 20. STCONSTCONSTCON is complete for NL.

A non-deterministic log-space Turing machine can guess a path from sss to ttt one node at a time, reusing space.

To show NL-hardness, Let LâˆˆNLL\in NLLâˆˆNL be accepted by non-deterministic log-space Turing machine MMM.

Given input xxx s.t. MMM accepts xxx iff there is a path in the configuration graph of MMM on input xxx from the initial configuration to an accepting configuration.

A log-space reduction from LLL to STCONSTCONSTCON is:

On input xxx we generate all configurations of MMM on input xxx, which then forms the set of nodes together with an additional node ttt. Initial configuration becomes the node sss.

Next generate all arcs between configurations corresponding to a single step of the Turing machine and finally arcs between all accepting configurations to the new node ttt. We then have that the resulting directed graph DDD has a path from sss to ttt iff MMM accepts xxx.

By Savitchâ€™s Theorem and Immerman-SzelepcsÃ©nyi Theorem, STCONâˆˆDSPACE(logâ¡2n)STCON\in DSPACE(\log^2n)STCONâˆˆDSPACE(log2n) and STCONâ€¾âˆˆNL\overline{STCON}\in NLSTCONâˆˆNL, respectively.

P/NP-completeness

Basic PPP and NPNPNP-complete problems are given by the ability of Boolean circuits to simulate Turing machines on fixed input length. For PPP this gives the circuit value problem.

CVP problem

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs and input xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n.

Question: Is C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

ğŸ¯Theorem 21. CVPCVPCVP is complete for PPP.

SAT problem

CircuitSAT

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs

Question: Does there exist xâˆˆ{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nxâˆˆ{0,1}n s.t. C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

ğŸ¯Theorem 22. CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT is complete for NPNPNP.

Let me use Chinese

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆ CircuitSAT å±äº NPNPNPã€‚ç®€å•ç†è§£å°±æ˜¯éç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœº NTM å¯ä»¥åœ¨å¤šé¡¹å¼æ—¶é—´è§£å†³æ­¤é—®é¢˜ã€‚ä¸€ä¸ªç®€å•çš„æ€æƒ³å°±æ˜¯æš´åŠ›æšä¸¾ï¼Œä¸€å…±éå† 2n2^n2n æ¬¡ã€‚è¿™æ ·åœ¨ç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœº DTM ä¸Šç¡®å®å°±æ˜¯ O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯åœ¨éç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºä¸Šï¼Œå°±å‰å®³äº†ã€‚é’ˆå¯¹æ¯ä¸€ä½ï¼Œéç¡®å®šæ€§å›¾çµæœºå¯ä»¥åŒæ—¶çŒœæµ‹ 000 å’Œ 111ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ä¸€å…±éå† nnn æ¬¡åˆ†åˆ«å¯¹åº” nnn ä½ï¼Œå°±å¾—åˆ°äº† NPNPNP çš„ç»“æœã€‚

As for NPNPNP-hard, construct language LâˆˆNTIME(nk)L\in NTIME(n^k)LâˆˆNTIME(nk) for k>0k\gt0k>0.

â€¦

SAT

Instance: CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

Question: Does Ï†\varphiÏ† have a satisfying assigment?

ğŸ¯Theorem 23. CNF satisfiability problem is also complete for NPNPNP.

Itâ€™s easy to see SATâˆˆNPSAT\in NPSATâˆˆNP.

For hardness, by reduction from CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT.

Given a Boolean circuit CCC, take Tseitin transformation of CCC giving an equi-satisfiable CNF formula Ï†\varphiÏ†.

This involves introducing new variable for each gate of CCC.

The number of new variable for each gate is a constant.

3SAT ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ NP çš„ï¼Œå³æ¯ä¸ªåˆå–èŒƒå¼æœ€å¤šåŒ…å«ä¸‰ä¸ªå­å¥ã€‚

PSPACE-completeness

Basic PSPACE-completeness is given by the problem of deciding validity of true quantified Boolean formulas as shown by Stockmeyer and Meyer. (TQBFTQBFTQBF)

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variable Ïˆ=Q1x1Q2x2â‹¯QnxnÏ†(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xn)\psi=Q_1x_1Q_2x_2\cdots Q_nx_n\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)Ïˆ=Q1â€‹x1â€‹Q2â€‹x2â€‹â‹¯Qnâ€‹xnâ€‹Ï†(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹), where Qiâˆˆ{âˆ€,âˆƒ}Q_i\in\{\forall,\exist\}Qiâ€‹âˆˆ{âˆ€,âˆƒ} and xiâˆˆ{0,1}x_i\in\{0,1\}xiâ€‹âˆˆ{0,1} for all iii.

Question: Is Ïˆ\psiÏˆ true?

ğŸ¯Theorem 24. TQBFTQBFTQBF is complete for PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE.

To see TQBFâˆˆPSPACETQBF\in PSPACETQBFâˆˆPSPACE: The algorithm is a recursion. At the bottom of the recursion, if Qi=âˆ€Q_i=\forallQiâ€‹=âˆ€, return 111 iff both returned 111; if Qi=âˆƒQ_i=\existQiâ€‹=âˆƒ, return 000 iff both returned 000. We of course need a stack with length O(n)O(n)O(n) for evaluating Ï†\varphiÏ†.

To show hardness, proof similar to Savitchâ€™s theorem.

â€¦

EXP/NEXP-completeness

Consider so-called succinct versions of complete problems of PPP and NPNPNP.

Let CCC be a Boolean circuit with nnn input gates and one output gate. The truthtable of CCC is the string tt(C)âˆˆ{0,1}2ntt(C)\in\{0,1\}^{2^n}tt(C)âˆˆ{0,1}2n giving the evaluation of CCC on all possible inputs.

Consider a language LâŠ†{0,1}âˆ—L\subseteq\{0,1\}^*LâŠ†{0,1}âˆ—. Then define the succinct version SuccinctLSuccinctLSuccinctL of LLL simply by SuccinctL={Câˆ£tt(C)âˆˆL}SuccinctL=\{C|tt(C)\in L\}SuccinctL={Câˆ£tt(C)âˆˆL}. Note that when LâˆˆPL\in PLâˆˆP we have that SuccinctLâˆˆEXPSuccinctL\in EXPSuccinctLâˆˆEXP simply by decompressing the input CCC to tt(C)tt(C)tt(C) in exponential time and then using the polynomial-time Turing machine to check for membership in LLL.

ç®€è€Œè¨€ä¹‹ï¼ŒæŠŠä¸Šé¢è¿™äº›ç©æ„çš„çœŸå€¼è¡¨ç®—å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å±äº EXP/NEXP çš„å¤æ‚åº¦ç±»ã€‚

Similarly we have SuccinctLâˆˆNEXPSuccinctL\in NEXPSuccinctLâˆˆNEXP when LâˆˆNPL\in NPLâˆˆNP.

ğŸ¯Theorem 25. SuccinctCVPSuccinctCVPSuccinctCVP is complete for EXPEXPEXP.

Similar transformation.

ğŸ¯Theorem 26. SucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSAT and SuccinctSATSuccinctSATSuccinctSAT are complete for NEXPNEXPNEXP.
